title: The other Republican budget battle
content:
Two senior Senate Republicans are preparing for a rare intraparty showdown over who will lead the Budget Committee , testing how big a platform the party will give one of the loudest conservative voices in the new GOP-controlled Congress .
The race between Jeff Sessions of Alabama and Mike Enzi of Wyoming will have critical implications for the GOP ’ s vision on nationwide budget policy , determine whether Sessions — one of the fiercest immigration-reform critics — will have a prime committee perch and show just how much seniority matters in today ’ s Senate GOP , which is about to get a youthful infusion of at least 11 new members in January .
While the two men have similarly conservative voting records , their styles couldn ’ t be more different : Sessions is a persistent partisan brawler , known for long floor speeches and sharp rhetoric , while the mild-mannered Enzi literally keeps his head down as he walks from his office to the Senate chamber , his mind buried in his tablet .
The future Budget chairman will have broad sway over the GOP ’ s policy visions , giving either Enzi a venue for his plan to produce a fiscal blueprint every two years or Sessions a platform for pushing a debt-slashing regimen that ’ s sometimes too aggressive even by Republican standards .
GOP leaders insist they are hands-off in this pitched race between two friends . It ’ s the Budget Committee members ’ votes that will ultimately determine whether Sessions — who isn ’ t afraid to buck a Republican leadership that wants to prove it can govern responsibly next year — will broadcast his strident conservatism with a gavel in hand or from the rank-and-file sidelines . Enzi , meanwhile , is viewed as a more reliable GOP team player less likely to cause waves within the conference .
“ Leadership has no role , ” insisted John Cornyn of Texas , the second-ranking Senate Republican .
Only Sen. Lindsey Graham ( R-S.C. ) would tip his hand , choosing to back Sessions , while the rest of the committee is likely to hide behind a secret ballot . But members of the conservative movement are openly pushing for Sessions ’ elevation , arguing he ’ s proved himself an effective conduit for the party ’ s right during his four years as the committee ’ s top Republican .
This battle between two senators from the party ’ s conservative wing is the Senate ’ s only contested committee race this year — and a rare test of whether seniority will be the end-all , be-all factor that could rocket Enzi to the powerful post . While many assumed that Sessions had proved his bona fides as ranking member of the committee and was all set for a promotion , Capitol Hill was blindsided by Enzi ’ s decision to exert his seniority over Sessions on the committee and challenge him for the post — seniority that was literally decided by a coin flip after the two men entered the Senate at the same time .
The race is forcing Republicans into a tough choice between two veteran senators who are their friends and colleagues — and few want to broadcast a vote that could alienate either Enzi or Sessions . The lone exception : Graham , who co-wrote the Senate ’ s immigration bill that Sessions vociferously opposed . And yet Sessions has his support .
“ I told Jeff I would be with Jeff . But I didn ’ t know there was a seniority problem ; I think that will matter to a lot of people . But I didn ’ t even know that Enzi was senior , ” Graham said . “ I feel bad in the sense that I [ committed ] before I knew what I was getting into . ”
The rest of the panel is tight-lipped . ███ asked all eight current Republicans on the panel , aside from Enzi and Sessions , whom they would support , and all , except for Graham , declined to answer . ( Republicans are also likely to pick up one or two more seats on the committee next year , and those new members will also have a vote . )
“ I ’ ve been asked three times today , ” Sen. Chuck Grassley ( R-Iowa ) said in a brief interview Tuesday . “ I said I ’ m not going to answer that question . ”
The mere prospect of Enzi seizing the gavel is , in turn , frustrating conservative outsiders who are backing Sessions .
“ This illustrates the disconnect between establishment Republicans and the voters . Why bench your all-star for a walk-on ? ” asked Gaston Mooney , executive director of the Conservative Review and a former aide to ex-Sen. Jim DeMint .
The National Review formally threw its support behind Sessions in an editorial last week , calling the Alabama senator “ one of the best advocates Republicans and conservatives have had on Capitol Hill for years . ”
Meanwhile , Weekly Standard editor William Kristol said in an email that although his publication doesn ’ t endorse candidates , “ I will say I think highly of Sessions , and think he ’ s done a very good job at the Budget Committee . ”
It ’ s yet to be seen if those outside views will sway senators . Both Enzi and Sessions plan to talk with all committee Republicans in private meetings in the coming weeks to discuss their vision for the panel , sources familiar with the process said .
Committee member Kelly Ayotte ( R-N.H. ) said Enzi ’ s seniority on the committee matters less than who can best unite the GOP ’ s disparate factions come next spring when Senate Republicans try to write a budget .
“ What I always want is someone who is going to listen to the views of all members , be respectful to them , ” said Ayotte — who will be meeting individually with both senators — ruling out seniority as the “ decider ” for her .
Some committee members are even holding out hope that Sessions and Enzi will reach some sort of agreement to avoid a divisive election between the Alabama firebrand and the low-key Wyomingite .
But don ’ t bet on it . An Enzi aide said the two are headed toward an election — and when asked if either candidate might drop out , Sessions said he had nothing to announce . The famously chatty Sessions declined to weigh in on his chances , and the delicate politics of the battle was accentuated by Enzi brushing off ███ four separate times in two days when asked to speak about the race .
“ We remain great friends , and my respect for him is high , ” Sessions said Wednesday . “ I ’ m not reporting on hour-by-hour [ movements ] . ”
While the conservative movement is pushing the narrative that Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-Ky. ) and his leadership team put Enzi up to the challenge , Republican leaders and Enzi ’ s office deny that assertion . Sessions himself said of Enzi : “ I think Mike makes up his own mind . ”
Many had speculated that Enzi might retire ahead of the last election cycle , but a primary challenge from Liz Cheney seemed to invigorate the genial senator ’ s political fire . After winning his seat back and with Republicans taking the majority for the first time since 2007 , it only made sense for Enzi to exert his seniority and pursue a high-profile chairmanship .
When Republicans last controlled the Senate , Enzi chaired the Senate Health , Employment , Labor and Pensions Committee ; it would have set off a different internal party challenge , against Sen. Lamar Alexander ( R-Tenn. ) , had he sought to once again lead the committee .
“ I thought he would take HELP , ” Sessions said . “ But that didn ’ t develop , apparently . ”
This illustrates the disconnect between establishment Republicans and the voters . Why bench your all-star for a walk-on ?
An Enzi aide said the senator had long had his eyes on the Budget Committee , one of the most sought-after posts in Congress . But it is also the one on which Sessions spent the past four years in the minority toiling as the panel ’ s top Republican , battling Democrats and , occasionally , GOP leaders and House Budget Chairman Paul Ryan ( R-Wis. ) .
Though some conservatives previously framed the Enzi-Sessions race as a broader fight over immigration , that component is becoming more muted .
Mark Krikorian , executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies , dismissed the notion that the gavel fight was becoming a proxy war on immigration , adding : “ I don ’ t even really think Sessions and Enzi would necessarily be all that different . ”
“ Is it the melody or the background music ? ” Krikorian asked of the immigration factor in the Enzi-Sessions fight . “ It sounds like it ’ s probably just background music . ”
With a challenge in the open , there ’ s also a possibility that someone else will enter the race .
One Republican source closely tracking the internal drama said a younger , fresher Budget Committee member could make the case that the committee needs some new energy — particularly now that the race is wide open .
“ You don ’ t need to have seniority to challenge a chairman in this system , ” this Republican said . “ Maybe we ’ ll have some more candidates … it could be anybody . ”
However , several GOP sources warned that many members of the Senate are cool to superseding seniority in any fashion . One Republican senator pointed out that Sessions beating the more senior Enzi for the post could create a chain reaction across the Senate ’ s committees .
